image.title: Alsea River & Drift Creek
image.caption: The Alsea River estuary holds some of the best remaining coastal coho spawning habitat on the West Coast. Photo: Russ Schnitzer » view project

image.title: Alsea River & Drift Creek
image.caption: Brown pelicans, which were only recently removed from the Endangered Species Act list, inhabit the Alsea River estuary. Photo Credit: Thomas Knoop » view project

image.title: Eel River
image.caption: WRC's conservation efforts in the Eel River estuary will help restore 440 acres of tidal wetlands. » view project

image.title: Eel River
image.caption: Marbled godwits, whose wingspans can reach nearly three feet, are one of many shorebirds that inhabit California's Eel River estuary. Photo Credit: Ron Wolf » view project

image.title: Elk River
image.caption: The Elk River supports one of the healthiest runs of coho salmon on the West Coast. Photo Credit: Thomas Kline » view project

image.title: Elk River
image.caption: Oregon's Elk River courses through dense old-growth forest and provides prime habitat for coho and Chinook salmon, steelhead and sea-run cutthroat trout. Photo Credit: Wood Sabold » view project

image.title: Elk River
image.caption: Pacific temperate rainforest surrounds Oregon's Elk River. Photo Credit: Russ Schnitzer » view project

image.title: Gunnison River
image.caption: WRC's work on the Gunnison River protects native warm-water fish, prevents riverside mining and increases access for boaters, anglers and other river enthusiasts. Photo Credit: Richard Drunan » view project

image.title: Gunnison River
image.caption: On the Gunnison River, WRC conveyed 617 acres to the BLM and prevented a gravel mine on the banks of this Colorado River tributary. Photo Credit: Russ Schnitzer » view project

image.title: Hood River
image.caption: Northern river otters inhabit hidden dens along the banks of the Hood River. Their range has been reduced by habitat loss. Photo Credit: Tom and Pat Leeson » view project

image.title: Hood River
image.caption: WRC's acquisitions on the Hood River permanently protect the confluence of the East and West forks (pictured) and Punch Bowl Falls, immediately upstream. Photo Credit: Steve Terrill » view project

image.title: John Day River
image.caption: Conservationist and WRC supporter Randy Labbe wades back to shore after a morning of steelhead fishing on the John Day River, inside what will soon become Cottonwood Canyon State Park. Photo Credit: Don Elder » view project

image.title: John Day River
image.caption: Sweeping gooseneck bends and towering basalt cliffs typify the 16-mile stretch of the John Day River that WRC protected. Photo Credit: Dave Jensen » view project

image.title: Klamath River & Blue Creek
image.caption: For Klamath River Chinook salmon, Blue Creek is a cold-water lifeline that allows them to stay cool enough to survive their journey upriver to spawn. Klamath salmon runs are some of the most recoverable on the West Coast. photo credit: Barrie Kovish » view project

image.title: Klamath River & Blue Creek
image.caption: Blue Creek is a lifesaving source of cold water for Klamath River salmon and a top conservation priority for WRC. Photo Credit: Dave Jensen » view project

image.title: Klamath River & Blue Creek
image.caption: The Blue Pool, at the confluence of Blue Creek and the Klamath River. Blue Creek is the first and most important cold-water refuge for wild salmon and steelhead on the lower Klamath. Photo Credit: Dave Jensen » view project

image.title: Klamath River
image.caption: » view project

image.title: Klamath Vallery Lupines
image.caption: » view project

image.title: Little Cimarron River
image.caption: During periods of low flow, this stretch of the Little Cimarron runs dry, disconnecting trout habitat between the upper and lower river. Photo Credit: Russ Schnitzer » view project

image.title: Little Cimarron River
image.caption: The upper reaches of the Little Cimarron are prime trout water. photo credit: RICHARD DURNAN » view project

image.title: Lower Deer Creek Falls
image.caption: In addition to conserving prime salmon and steelhead habitat, WRC's efforts on Deer Creek complete a popular riverside trail. Photo Credit: Jenny Duvander » view project

image.title: Lower Deer Creek Falls
image.caption: Deer Creek is one of the last streams in the Sierra Nevada with healthy runs of spring Chinook and steelhead. photo credit: CINDY DIAZ » view project

image.title: Minam River
image.caption: » view project

image.title: Minam River
image.caption: Thousands of boaters, anglers and hikers visit the Minam River every year to enjoy its rugged beauty. Photo Credit: Leon Werdinger » view project

image.title: minam-river
image.caption: WRC's recent work on the Minam River places a favorite boating access area into public hands for good. Photo Credit: Dave Jensen » view project

image.title: Nason Creek
image.caption: The first pack of gray wolves known to reinhabit Washington state was identified in the Okanogan-Wenatchee National Forest. Photo Credit: Tom and Pat Leeson » view project

image.title: Nason Creek
image.caption: WRC's acquisition above Nason Creek, a key cold-water tributary of the Wenatchee River, improves habitat for native fish and wildlife. Photo Credit: Lee Rentz » view project

image.title: North Santiam
image.caption: A steelhead angler fishes through the North Santiam conservation property, which protects two miles of river frontage. Photo Credit: STEVE TERRILL » view project

image.title: North Santiam
image.caption: WRC is conserving the most intact tract of native riparian forest on the lower North Santiam River. Photo Credit: Steve Terrill » view project

image.title: Salmon River
image.caption: Chinook (pictured), sockeye and steelhead migrate over 900 miles to spawn in the Salmon River. Photo Credit: Tom and Pat Leeson » view project

image.title: Salmon River
image.caption: From a rocky outcrop, a hiker looks out over the remote Salmon River property that WRC committed to purchase in 2012. Photo Credit: Dave Jensen » view project

image.title: Sandy River
image.caption: Rafters float the Sandy River, which now flows freely from the glaciers of Mount Hood to the Columbia River, passing within 15 miles of downtown Portland. Photo Credit: NW River Guides » view project

image.title: Sandy River
image.caption: Critical habitat for salmon and steelhead, Boulder Creek is one of four key Sandy River tributaries that WRC has protected in partnership with the BLM and PGE. Photo Credit: Steve Terrill » view project

image.title: Yampa River
image.caption: WRC's efforts on the Yampa create new access to the Cross Mountain Wilderness Study Area, home to one of the continentâ€™s largest herds of Rocky Mountain elk. Photo Credit: Dave Dietrich » view project

image.title: Yampa River
image.caption: WRC's acquisition on the Yampa River opens access to Cross Mountain Canyon (foreground), immediately downstream from the conservation property. Photo Credit: Rob Hanna » view project
